page.title: 02GEOLOGY & LANDSCAPE: WARLEY
page.content: To the north east of the block rises the{Warley Ridge,}connected to the more northerly{Brentwood Ridge, reaching a height of 109m. In contrast the far south west of the block is only 20m. above sea level. The area has many minor undulations. These variations largely reflect geological differences. The lowest ground is mostly comprised of{London Clay,} occupying nearly two-thirds of the block. Above this lie progressively the late Tertiary{Claygate Beds}and on top of that the{Bagshot Beds.}These give rise to sandier soils and support a different type of land use. Highest of all are the{Pleistocene}superficial deposits of the{Pebble Gravel}and {Warley Gravel:}these beds today support mostly woodland.
